text: non compliance with engineering standard during lifting operations migrated from legacy cairs incident #29064non compliance with engineering standard during lifting operations.offshore review of incident has taken place. see attached slide pack and oim statement.onshore wgpsn investigation to be conducted, see attached interview notes with slfp involved migrated from legacy cairs - see detailed description

14.11.16 ykk subcontractor felt himself unwell, and spent two days at home with a high temperature. company then sought medical aid at the hospital and was diagnosed with pneumonia of the lung. migrated from legacy cairs incident #31748ykk subcontractor felt himself unwell, and spent two days at home with a high temperature.then he was sent to hospital formedical aid at the hospital, doctorsdiagnosedhim aspneumonia of the lung. now his condition much better.sick person lives in uk and company arranged/booked flight for him for 20.11.16 to get further treatment in his city in uk but because of weather conditions it was canceled to the nearest flight. migrated from legacy cairs - see detailed description

wood electrical tech suffered minor bruising to bridge of his nose after impacting with horizontal scaffold tube. migrated from legacy cairs incident #37723a wood electrical tech was walking from his worksite via the west side of north- south pipe rack at stab 1. he was at grade level when he encountered a horizontal scaffold tube protruding out at head height which was obscured by the peak of his hard hat. the bridge of the operatives nose impacted with the tube causing some bruising in the area. the site medic was unavailable.a ice pack was issued to the ip by a first aider and a visit was carried out to the medic the following morning, where he was checked over and advised that he was fit to work. migrated from legacy cairs - see detailed description
eight members of contractor project team tested positive for covid-19 eight workers were onsite for rotation on mar 1 & 2 and tested positive. isolation initiated.

a contractor's employee tripped over the pallet causing pain in his left shoulder approximately at 4.30 pm at level 3 area eb u 41, the contractor's employee while trying to move a podium ladder accidentally tripped over a wooden pallet and fell at ground causing pain in his left shoulder. the worker receive first aid treatment at site and he was subsequently taken to hospital for checks.amecfw hsse and discipline supervision start conducting interview to the involved people to understand the causes of this event.

a wood employee tested positive for covid-19  a wood employee was reported to wood supervision that they began to experience cov19 s/s on 1/16/2022.  the wood employee scheduled a covid 19 test on 1/17/2022, and was informed on 1/17/2022 the employee is positive for cov19. the employee was last on site on 1/14/2022. contact tracing has been completed, no direct contacts identified.  employee has self quarantined and has notified management.  wood on site management has conducted contact tracing and notification to client.

category: hand or arm injury, foot or leg injury
text: ip received minor cut to finger whilst cleaning compartment on hms kent migrated from legacy cairs incident #36564ip was cleaning compartment on hms kent and noticed a pile of rags and general rubbish. as he began to clear the rubbish; he picked up with his hands but didn’t notice a razor blade within the rubbish. ip was wearing gloves but not cut resistant, resulting in minor cut to finger, ip was seen by onsite medic, plaster applied but no further action required and returned back to work.awaiting update from on-site advisor – late report due to cairs error in last week. migrated from legacy cairs - see detailed description

foreign body entry to left eye when grinding paint on cellar deck ip was grinding paint on the north side of the cellar deck interconnecting beams when he felt something enter his left eye. he was wearing an airfed 3m mask at the time which was brand new. he removed the mask, rubbed his eye and felt no further irritation and so did not report to the medic at the time. none, felt no further irritation - reported to medic at later date

landlord roof works caused rainwater leak into server room. landlord is having building works undertaken on the roof. when it rained, rainwater entered the server room and ups room. sheeting placed above to protect servers and ups with work to be completed in 5-10 days. sheeting placed over servers to protect. meeting held with it team to ensure business continuity. building company put additional measures to prevent reoccurrence

mechanic performing excavator maintenance/servicing work at site but that activity was not included in the wood permit-to-work document.  on 15-sep-2020 at 15.30 hrs,  one of the em staff visited the site and checked permit-to-work document. during the time inspection, it was observed that the contractor mechanic was performing excavator maintenance/servicing work at site but that activity was not included in the wood permit-to-work document. the standard practice is that our permit applicant always include the equipment maintenance/servicing activity in the wood permit-to-work (ptw) and few days ago permit applicant removed the equipment maintenance/servicing activity from the list of ptw. by over sight and under the assumption that the equipment maintenance/servicing activity is already captured as usual in the permit, the site supervisor allowed the mechanic to carry out the equipment maintenance/servicing activity at site. stopped work;initiated investigation process

it came to light the rig should have not been in use following a hydraulic issue found when the rig was serviced following the previous incidents that have occurred with the window sample drilling rig the drillers have now let slip that the company that are employed to maintain the rig recommended that during the recent service that the rig should not be used due to the hydraulic system on the rig failing. the rig is to be removed from site and not used anymore. gts who employed the drilling rig have agreed to not use the company again.

a pmc vehicle with driver and pmc qa/qc inspector was hit from behind by a third party vehicle whislt stationary at traffic lights. the pmc qa/qc inspector was travelling as a front seat passenger from mina ahmadi greenfield to block 12 to undertake an inspection. after exiting highway 30, the driver of the pmc vehicle proceeded to stop at the traffic light intersection (approximately 500 m after turn off) behind another vehicle. after stopping, the pmc vehicle was impacted from behind by a third party vehicle (truck) which pushed the pmc vehicle into the vehicle in front causing damage to the rear and front of the pmc vehicle.  wood cfp deputy pd and wood me pmc senior hssea manager notified telephonically by pmc cfp hse director.pmc qa/qc inspector taken to medical centre (epc) for check up. driver requested to attend police station immediately post incident.pmc qa/qc inspector and driver taken to new mowasat clinic for independent assessment.(qa/qc inspector undergoing x-rays on lower left leg, results pending).

category: line strike, lifting or moving loads
text: operator was excavating a trench to install fire pump conduit. operator struck a known gas line with the bucket. gas line was not in use.  a permit was issued to fpcl for an excavation to install electrical conduit for fire water at chester camp by wood. the excavation permit outlined hand digging to expose a known gas line.   the operator signed off the permit, jha, and completed a flra then began excavating as per the permit. a ground man was positioned to dig in the area of the gas line. the groundman began scraping the dirt in the area with a shovel then stopped. the operator dug into the ground and struck the gas line damaging it.  the work was stopped and the incident reported to fpcl safety. wood hsse department notified and investigation initiated.

a pair of safety gloves left nearby a hot work location started smoldering and caught fire.  safety gloves that were left on the scaffolding platform nearby / underneath a hot work location started smoldering and caught fire (super-heater, tie-in 01). these safety gloves, nearby this hot work location, were not observed during their pre-inspection. most likely hidden in-between the fire blankets.  due to a prompt intervention by the g4s fire guards the small fire (smoldering) was extinguished immediately, without further consequences.  #name?

instrument air line damaged while installing a steel support column using a crane, the column came in contact with an instrument air line in close proximity to final installation point.  a section of the air line came loose at a t-piece causing air to be released. area around loose t-piece barricadedarea supervisor, hse and manager informedisolation of airline initiated to conduct repair.

category: lifting or moving loads, vehicle incident general
text: the ee slid off the side of the road in snowy conditions and struck a mailbox causing damage to a wood truck. on december 10 at approx. 0430, a wood employee was commuting to work. the ee was driving down lawver rd in snowy conditions with reduced visibility. an oncoming vehicle was intruding into the ee’s lane, so the wood employee attempted to move the vehicle over closer to the right side of road to avoid a collision. in doing so the ee struck a mailbox damaging the passenger side front grill guard with a dent, scratches along the passenger side, front and back door, and impacting the rear wheel well damaging the fender. actual severity is a1 because the damage was less than 10k. the potential severity is a1 as it is unlikely that damage would have exceeded 10k. stopped, looked at damage, contacted supervisor and hse.

two subcontractor employees were involved in an a physical altercation.   two subcontractor employees were involved in an a physical altercation within the casting building. one employee struck the other with a fall protection cheater. the employee that was struck with the cheater was taken to the local occupational clinic for examination. both employees have been removed from the project.  the actual severity rating is a b1 due to the medical evaluation. the potential severity is a b-2 due to the possibility of an injury requiring medical treatment. the employee who required a medical examination was taken to the clinic. both employees were terminated.
confirmed positive for covid-19 employee received positive covid-19 test results. contact tracing is underway.

category: vehicle Incident involving animal, lifting or moving loads, vehicle incident general
text: wgpacs employee was driving down hwy 181 when a large bird hit the windshield. migrated from legacy cairs incident #31104wgpacs employee was driving down hwy 181 during early morning hours when a large bird struck and cracked the windshield. there were no injuries. migrated from legacy cairs - see detailed description

one wood employee tested positive for covid 19 during premobilization screening.  one wood employee tested positive for covid 19 during premobilization screening. ee is asymptomatic and returned home for quarantine. no contact tracing required.  ee instructed to quarantine and retest after quarantine.

1 contractor assigned in onshore gas plant tested positive for covid19 1 contrcator assigned in onshore gas plant tested positive for covid19. the personnel is currently asymptomatic and is now jointly monitored by the contractor's oh team. the case was referred to the local government health team for coordination and recording. the ip was sent home for isolation is currently monitored by their company oh team.

woodgroup operative witnessed carrying out an unsafe act by passing underneath a stationary tank truck vehicle.medium potential  classified with investigation to follow migrated from legacy cairs incident #33922on the 25th may 2017 at approximately 07:40am a wood group employee was witnessedpassing under a road tankerfrom one side of the vehicle to the other.this happened within the gsk montrose main security gate house where access from the pedestrian walkway into the gatehouse is via a zebra crossing. the zebra crossing allows access to and from the security gatehouse and the pedestrian walkway where operatives / visitors can access the main site turnstiles.vehicle access to the site is by the main access road where vehicles/ tankers / goods lorries will gain entry via 2 security controlled barriers. the initial barrier allows vehicles to enter a waiting zone which would place the vehicles dependent on size across the zebra crossing that gives access to and from the security gatehouse. at this waiting zone a secondary barrier is present where a swipe system is required prior to vehicle entry through the second gate and onto site.the wood group operative had been accessing the zebra crossing from the main security gatehouse where the waiting road tanker had been sitting in the waiting zone prior to being granted access through the second barrier. the operative seeing the obstruction in front of him decided to access to the pedestrianwalkway by going underneath the stationary vehicle.the incident was witnessed by gsk security staff and was reported to gsk management and wgis site manager. after a short interview with the site manager the operative was removed from site and his pass was suspended. the operative was told by the wgis site manager that he would be in touch as part of the investigation.as part of an on-going site drawdown the operative in question was paid off before any further investigation could take place. it should be noted that the individual had been nominated for pay off before the incident and his departure was not as a result of the incident. migrated from legacy cairs - see detailed description

category: vehicle Incident involving animal, vehicle incident general
text: deer ran out in front of 4x4 vehicle the foreman and passenger were travelling to site in the company vehicle  along the a897 towards helmsdale when a deer ran out in front of the vehicle colliding with the front panel and passenger side bumper causing damage to both panels.  the deer survived the contact and ran off onto the nearby moorland.  the foreman and passenger were travelling to site in the company vehicle  along the a897 towards helmsdale when a deer ran out in front of the vehicle colliding with the front panel and passenger side bumper causing damage to both panels.  the deer survived the contact and ran off onto the nearby moorland.

preventable - fleet vehicle - no injuries our driver was traveling on a mining site down an undefined road in the rain on a rough road. while driving, vehicle hit a rutt in the road and it ripped the skirting off from under the front bumper. employee notified supervisor and a claim was filed with donlen.

subcontractor communicated a positive confirmation for covid-19 to site management subcontractor reported a confirmed positive test for covid-19. the subcontractor employee has been in self-isolation. subcontractor/wood identifying those who may have worked in proximity.  appropriate notifications have been completed.

primary electrical feeder cables for taziway lighting cut during mine and explosive clearance (mec) excavation work subcontractor crews were using a mini excavator to expose an existing duct bank during mec related excavation operations.  during the process, crew noted that the ductbank ended abruptly about 2 meters from the handhole and did not appear to terminate at the handhole as expected.  as the crew excavated towards the handhole and beyond where the ductbank stopped, they noted two exposed cables.  crews assumed that cables were part of same electrical cable that was previously disconnected and did not consider it an active line.  it was noted the next day that the two wires were the primary feeder for the taxiway lighting circuit and the damage caused the taxiway lights to be inoperable when the circuit was closed. airbase maintenance crew detected break and repaired.  digging permit renewed after new utility line survey.  crews underwent refresher training on specified procedures for excavation in close proximity to known utility locations

category: general injury, hand or arm injury
text: ip cut knuckle on traffic cone ip went to put the two stacked cones on shoulder to carry them easier, however the outside cone was missing the upper section, and this was not held in place securely.  as the cones were vertical the outside cone slid down on to ips hand, cutting the knuckle. the other team member preformed first aid.
massy wood employee tested positive for covid 19 virus. massy wood employee tested positive for covid 19 virus. employee is currently in formal quarantine.

forklift contacted handrail a team member operating a 12k extendable boom forklift was lifting a scaffold rack with material on it weighing <500lbs. the team member had the boom of the forklift extended out approximately 18-20’ over two handrails for the trench that ran between the filter collector and the vacuum producer. when the lift was initiated the boom deflected in an up and down motion causing it to come into contact with the top of the handrail on the vacuum producer side of the trench, bending the rail.  spotters were being utilized. scene secured, management notified, and investigation initiated.

text: other fall to lower level, unspecified an employee was on a ladder installing an electric metallic tube. while attaching the tubing, the employee was startled by a shock and slipped off the ladder, falling to the ground and breaking his wrist. he was hospitalized.

inhalation of harmful substance-single episode employees were starting the granulator when ammonia bypassed the control valve and bled into the granulator. fumes were released while the employees were nearby, causing chemical burns, respiratory illness, and unconsciousness. two employees were hospitalized.

category: lifting or moving loads, foot or leg injury
text: struck by powered vehicle-nontransport, n.e.c. an employee was helping a carry deck crane operator deliver items to the field. he followed the crane in a golf cart to the fab tent to retrieve equipment. as he was walking out of the fab tent with a strap in his hand and looking down at the strap to perform a visual inspection, the crane operator was putting his outriggers down. they did not see each other and an outrigger caught the employee's big toe. the outrigger smashed the steel toe of his boot, splitting and breaking his big toe.

explosion, unspecified employees were performing normal daily tasks within the rendering department when a natural gas explosion occurred in the furnace of the blood dried system. two employees were hospitalized with burns and other injuries.
